name: Angels Landing
description: A thrilling ridge hike in Zion with steep drop offs and stunning canyon views.
safety_tips: Start early to avoid crowds and heat.
Bring plenty of water, there are no refill stations.
Wear grippy hiking shoes due to narrow paths and drop offs.
Do not attempt in bad weather, high risk of falls.

name: The Narrows
description: A unique river hike through narrow sandstone canyons in Zion National Park.
safety_tips: Check for flash flood warnings before entering.
Wear water shoes and neoprene socks.
Use a walking stick for balance.
Waterproof your gear.

name: Delicate Arch
description: An iconic hike to Utah's most famous natural arch in Arches National Park.
safety_tips: Bring sun protection—there is no shade.
Start early to avoid crowds.
Watch your footing near the arch.
Carry at least 1 liter of water per hour.

name: The Wave (Coyote Buttes North)
description: A surreal sandstone formation with wave like patterns (permit required).
safety_tips: Permits are required—plan ahead.
Use a GPS or map, trail is not marked.
Bring extra water and a backup power bank.
Avoid summer midday heat.

name: Bryce Canyon Rim Trail
description: A scenic trail with panoramic views of Bryce Canyon's unique hoodoo formations.
safety_tips: Stay behind railings at viewpoints.
Be cautious during icy or snowy conditions.
Wear layers, weather changes quickly.
Bring snacks and water.

name: Peek-a-Boo & Spooky Gulch
description: Adventurous slot canyon loop with tight squeezes and rock scrambling.
safety_tips: Do not attempt during or after rain.
Bring gloves for scrambling.
Travel light, canyons are narrow.
Let someone know your route.

name: Mount Timpanogos
description: A strenuous summit hike offering wildflowers, waterfalls, and 360° views.
safety_tips: Bring layers, summit can be cold even in summer.
Start before sunrise to avoid storms.
Watch for wildlife, including mountain goats.
Carry extra food and water.

name: Observation Point
description: An incredible overlook in Zion, higher than Angels Landing with fewer crowds.
safety_tips: Watch for loose gravel on switchbacks.
Avoid midday heat, trail is exposed.
Use hiking poles for downhill support.
Take frequent breaks to hydrate.

name: Corona Arch
description: A short but scenic trail near Moab to a massive natural arch.
safety_tips: Watch for slippery slickrock sections.
Follow cairns to stay on trail.
Use caution on the ladder section.
Bring plenty of water.

name: Devils Garden Trail
description: A loop through Arches with several spectacular arches and sandstone fins.
safety_tips: Trail can be confusing, watch for markers.
Wear good shoes for rocky terrain.
Bring navigation and extra water.
Start early to beat the heat.

name: Kanarra Falls
description: A beautiful slot canyon hike with ladders and flowing waterfalls (permit required).
safety_tips: Permits are required—buy ahead of time.
Use caution on wet ladders and rocks.
Protect electronics from water.
Don’t attempt if flash flood risk is high.

name: Calf Creek Falls
description: A pleasant desert trail leading to a stunning 126 foot waterfall.
safety_tips: Bring a hat and sunscreen, there is no shade.
Swimming is allowed, bring a towel.
Watch for rattlesnakes.
Drink plenty of water.

name: Capitol Gorge Trail
description: A short hike through a scenic canyon with petroglyphs and historic inscriptions.
safety_tips: Don’t climb on rock formations.
Stay on marked paths to preserve history.
Be prepared for hot temperatures.
Check the weather for storm risk.

name: Red Cliffs Desert Reserve
description: A collection of scenic trails through lava rock and red desert landscapes.
safety_tips: Watch for snakes and lizards on the trail.
Don’t touch cryptobiotic soil.
Wear sunscreen and a hat.
Stay hydrated, there are no water sources on trail.

name: Little Wild Horse Canyon
description: A fun and family friendly loop through narrow sandstone slot canyons.
safety_tips: Avoid slot canyons during storm forecasts.
Bring a headlamp for dim sections.
Leave no trace, pack out all trash.
Let someone know your route and ETA.
